            CULTURAL HERITAGE

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Cultural Heritage
            Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory
            and borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: projects should be fully
            designed and costed before appraisal. Investment projects
            should not be allowed to go for Board approval without
            advanced preparation or completion of the final design
            studies and cost estimates for all components, in agreement
            with the relevant country authorities. Investment in
            cultural heritage is a complex process that requires a
            combination of lending instruments and technical support. As
            evidenced in similar operations worldwide, museum and art
            center projects are always difficult and require a
            preparation that is both time consuming and
            resource-intensive. Ownership and commitment to key reforms
            should play a central role in risk evaluation. Economic
            benefits can be very high for cultural heritage investments.
            Especially in the cultural heritage sector, even low cost
            investments that are strategically selected and positioned
            can have a decisive impact. Need for a longer-term sector engagement.
